bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: "Old Age echoes," [1891]
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.head: Old age Echoes—
Sounds of the winter
lg.l:
Sunshine upon the mountains—many a distant
strain

From cheery railroad train—from nearer field,
barn house,

The whispering air—even the mute crops, gar-
ner'dgarnered
apples, corn,

Children's and women's tones—rhythm of many
a farmer and of flail,

An old man's garrulous lips among the rest, Think
not we give out yet,

l.hi: Forth from these snowy hairs we two keep up the lilt.

lg.head: The Unexpress'd—
lg.l: After the cycles, poems, singers, plays,

Vaunted Ionia's, India's—Homer, Shakespere—the long,
long times' thick dotted roads, areas,

The shining clusters and the Milky Ways of
stars—Nature's pulses reap'd,

All retrospective passions, heros, war, love,
adoration,
All ages' plummets dropt to their utmost depths,

All human lives, throats, wishes, brains—all
experiences' found utterance

After the countless songs, or long or short, all tongues,
all lands

Still something, not yet told in poesy's voice
or print—something lacking,
(Who knows? the best yet unexpress'd and lacking.)

lg.note: put in type for greater correctness & my own convenience

lg.l:
A group of ‸wee children with their ways and
chatter flow in

Like welcome rippling water o'er my heated
nerves and flesh.
